cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications: price determination, market structure, decision making by individuals and firms, public policy. NOTE: extensive use of graphical and quantitative analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Microeconomics
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
MCV4U (Calculus & Vectors) and MHF4U (Advanced Functions), or equivalent secondary school mathematics credits

Distribution Requirement: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

WW CHRM Certificate in Human Resources Management students are also eligible to enrol when course enrolment becomes available.

Delivery Instructions

LEC0101 & 5101: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule, and students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

LEC0201 & 0301: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications from a macroeconomic (economy-wide) perspective. Topics covered include international trade and finance, role of money and the banking system, monetary and fiscal policy. Note: graphical and quantitative analysis are used extensively.
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
MCV4U (Calculus & Vectors) and MHF4U (Advanced Functions), or equivalent secondary school mathematics credits

Distribution Requirement: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

WW CHRM Certificate in Human Resources Management students are also eligible to enrol when course enrolment becomes available.

Delivery Instructions

L0101+5101: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule, and students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

L0201+0301: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Theory of markets and prices. Determination of prices through the interaction of the basic economic units, the household as consumer and as supplier of inputs and the business firm as producer and as employer of inputs. The pricing system as the mechanism by which social decisions and allocation of goods are made in a market economy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Microeconomic Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities

cmCourseInfo.description: Theory of output, employment and the price level; techniques for achieving economic stability; central banking and Canadian financial institutions and markets; foreign exchange markets and the exchange rate. This course is not intended for students enrolled in the BCom program; please see ECO209Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Macroeconomic Theory and Policy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

In all following elements, any platform or software, approved by the economics department might be used. 

  • Lectures will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • Tutorials will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • The Instructor and TAs office hours (Question/Answer sessions) will be held online synchronously (live at specific times).
  • Term tests and assessments will be held online, generally between 2 to 3 hours per assessment, within 6 to 10-hour windows to accommodate different time zones. Some adjustments could be made in order to proctor the assessments.
  • There will also be online quizzes, generally between 2 to 3 hours per quiz, within three-day windows to complete.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deals more rigorously and more mathematically with the topics included in ECO200Y1 and is intended primarily for students in certain Economics Specialist programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Microeconomic Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Lecture recordings and tutorial slides will be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deals more rigorously and more mathematically with the topics included in ECO202Y1 and is intended primarily for students in certain Economics Specialist programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Macroeconomic Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will be posted online for students to view asynchronously. However, tutorials, office hours, and assessments will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Introduction to Data Analysis and Applied Econometrics

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: April 28, 2021: Section added.

cmCourseInfo.description: Numerical and graphical data description; data collection and sampling; probability; sampling distributions; statistical inference; hypothesis testing and estimation; simple and multiple regression analysis (extensive coverage). Learn how to analyze data and how to correctly interpret and explain results. Use Excel to analyze a wide variety of data and replicate tables and figures in economics research papers.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Data Analysis and Applied Econometrics
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: GGR270H1, PSY201H1, PSY202H1, SOC202H1, SOC252H1, STA220H1, STA221H1, STA248H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students in LEC0201 must enroll in a tutorial (ie. TUT0101, TUT0201, TUT0301).

Delivery Instructions

LEC0101+0301: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. 

LEC0201: Lectures are offered online synchronously on Tuesdays, and online asynchronously on Thursdays. Students are strongly encouraged to attend the live synchronous elements, but recordings are provided for review. Students in LEC0201 must enroll in a tutorial (ie. TUT0101, TUT0201, TUT0301).

cmCourseInfo.description: This course demonstrates how a rigorous application of microeconomic techniques can inform our responses to various environmental problems. Topics may include: air and water pollution and renewable resource management.
cmCourseInfo.title: Environmental Economics and Policies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

In all following elements, any platform or software, approved by the economics department might be used. 

  • Lectures will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • Tutorials will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • The Instructor and TAs office hours (Question/Answer sessions) will be held online synchronously (live at specific times).
  • Assessments will be held online, generally between 2 to 3 hours per assessment, within 6 to 10-hour windows to accommodate different time zones. Some adjustments could be made in order to proctor the assessments.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course surveys important features of energy markets and related environmental challenges. One of the central objectives is to provide an understanding of the key economic tools needed to analyse these markets. A related objective is the development of a framework for understanding the public discourse on energy and the environment. Topics include: the hydrocarbon economy (oil, natural gas and coal), electricity markets, global warming and other externalities, renewable energy, conservation, carbon taxes and ‘cap-and-trade’.
cmCourseInfo.title: Energy and the Environment
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are conducted synchronously. These are recorded and posted online. There will be no in-person sessions. Tests are synchronous with all students writing at the same time during the scheduled time-slot. You must have access to a computer or a tablet with a reliable internet connection in order to participate, download and upload materials, watch posted videos and write tests at specified times.

cmCourseInfo.description:
Focuses on the core ideas and concepts of game theory and on applications of them in economics and other social sciences. Topics may include: oligopoly, electoral competition, the theory of public goods, voting theory, the free rider problem, repeated interaction, bargaining, evolutionary equilibrium, matching and auctions.

Note: This course cannot be taken as a substitute in programs that require ECO326H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Applied Game Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities

cmCourseInfo.description: The practical application of microeconomic theory to common legal problems: torts, contracts, property and crime, and the limitations of economic analysis. No previous familiarity with the law is assumed. (This is an economic analysis of legal issues, not a course in law).
cmCourseInfo.title: Economic Analysis of Law

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: The practical application of microeconomic theory to common legal problems: torts, contracts, property and crime, and the limitations of economic analysis. No previous familiarity with the law is assumed. (This is an economic analysis of legal issues, not a course in law).
cmCourseInfo.title: Economic Analysis of Law

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: A development of the microeconomic foundations of macroeconomic theory to expand students' analytic skills by constructing and solving macroeconomic models. Topics may include: dynamic choice, neoclassical growth theory, uncertainty and rational expectations, business cycles, as well as fiscal and monetary policy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Economic Theory - Macro

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: February 25, 2021: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: Ample empirical and experimental evidence suggests significant departures from classical assumptions of economic behaviour. For example, humans are neither always perfectly rational nor always self interested. This course describes systematic ways in which behaviour deviates from neoclassical assumptions, generating new, and hopefully more realistic behavioural assumptions that have broad empirical, theoretical and policy implications.
cmCourseInfo.title: Behavioural and Experimental Economics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be predominately asynchronous, with some minor synchronous elements. Lectures will be posted as online videos, and students will have the chance to engage with the course material and each other through online discussion boards, and will complete all work digitally. Students will have flexibility in the timing of their course work, but will need to keep up to date with the course material, and be actively participating in the course on a regular basis, much like with a traditional course. Additionally, some course elements (participation in experiments), will require students to be available during one of several scheduled times. Students will need reliable Internet access via a computer with a working microphone.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: February 25, 2021: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: Spatial economic theory and urban public policy: firms and individuals in partial and general equilibrium, land development and land-use controls, urban transportation, efficiency and equity in spending and taxing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Urban Economics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be online asynchronous. Tutorials will be online synchronous and recorded for asynchronous viewing. There will be synchronous online class discussions once per week and regular online office hours. Exams will be online synchronous.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies the interaction of the monetary and banking sectors with financial markets and the broader economy. It builds especially on tools developed in intermediate macroeconomics, but also focuses on the institutional structure of the Canadian monetary sector, including the role and operation of the Bank of Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Money, Banking and Financial Markets
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The course has asynchronous and synchronous elements. Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies the interaction of the monetary and banking sectors with financial markets and the broader economy. It builds especially on tools developed in intermediate macroeconomics, but also focuses on the institutional structure of the Canadian monetary sector, including the role and operation of the Bank of Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Money, Banking and Financial Markets
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses may be offered in one or more subjects each year. Students must meet the prerequisites announced by the Department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Economics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See the Department of Economics website for details.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

See department website for course prerequisites.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered as per course schedule. In special circumstances, recordings of lectures will also be made available for students to view asynchronously. Since participation during lectures is an important element of the course, It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economics of financial assets and financial markets. Topics: inter-temporal choice, expected utility theory, security valuation, selected asset pricing models, market efficiency, and the term structure of interest rates - essential materials for an understanding of the role and operation of financial markets.
cmCourseInfo.title: Financial Economics I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Agency and incomplete information problems inherent in financial transactions; the role of contractual arrangements in overcoming them. Financial constraints on investment decisions of firms; the financial system in economic growth; the legal system in the functioning of financial markets. A look at theoretical and empirical literature covering these issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Financial Economics II: Corporate Finance

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the causes and consequences of international trade. The first half develops traditional models of comparative advantage. The second half examines more recent theoretical and empirical work on trade & wages, the political economy of trade, outsourcing, and firm heterogeneity.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Trade Theory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to open economy macroeconomics and international finance. The core objective of the course is to develop macroeconomic models of open economies that can be applied towards gaining an understanding of recent events such as US deficits, financial crises, China's exchange rate policy and the Euro.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Monetary Economics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to econometrics similar to ECO375H1, with greater focus on applications drawn from business and financial economics. The course is built around the statistical foundations and economic applications of the multiple regression model. Using statistical software, students will also learn how to conduct, present, and critique empirical research.
cmCourseInfo.title: Forecasting and Time Series Econometrics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures and tutorials will be available for students to view asynchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to econometrics. Statistical foundations and the interpretation of multiple regression models, with an emphasis on cross-sectional data. Application of regressions to a wide variety of economic questions and data sources, including the use of statistical software. Problems in the identification of causality, and an introduction to methods of addressing common statistical issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Applied Econometrics I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures and tutorials will be available for students to view asynchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course in applied microeconomics is concerned with the functioning of markets and the behaviour of firms within these markets. The focus is on strategic relationships between organizations, including competitive relationships among firms in the same market and cooperative relationships between a firm and its suppliers and distributors.
cmCourseInfo.title: Markets, Competition, and Strategy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides a general treatment of the economics of energy markets and the use of regulation in addressing environmental and other issues arising in these markets. A central theme is the search for an appropriate balance between market forces and regulatory/government intervention. Familiarity with tools of microeconomics and statistics/econometrics is essential. Topics include: oil, natural gas, coal and electricity markets, global warming and other externalities, networks, feed-in-tariffs, carbon taxes, ‘cap-and-trade’ and incentive regulation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Energy and Regulation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials are conducted synchronously. These are recorded and posted online. There will be no in-person sessions. Tests are synchronous with all students writing at the same time during the scheduled time-slot. You must have access to a computer or a tablet with a reliable internet connection in order to participate, download and upload materials, watch posted videos and write tests at specified times.

NOTE: For Financial Economics Specialist students, this course may be used to fulfill the 3rd year or higher 1.0 FCE course list. Contact department for details.

Since participation during lectures is an important element of the course, It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

notes.content: April 5, 2021: Course cancelled.

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses may be offered in one or more subjects each year. Students must meet the prerequisites announced by the Department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Economics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See the Department of Economics website for details.

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the price, distribution, and growth theories of major economic thinkers before 1870, from pre-classical contributions by Aristotle, Mercantilists, and Physiocrats to the classical authors Adam Smith, David Ricardo, T.R. Malthus, and Karl Marx.
cmCourseInfo.title: Classical Economic Thought

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities (ie. Quercus discussion groups). BbCollaborate will be used.
